PRESIDENT’S MEMO
THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
Washington, DX»
August 17., 1961
Following up on my promise at the Madison Seminar, I am hereby re-insti-
tuting the practice of sending the Board of Directors a monthly informal memo to keep
them more fully abreast of current, activities of the Association, progress of projects
s*in the works3 8, and plans for future developments.
I agree with the criticism voiced by SchwartzwaIcier and others that the Board
is not being kept sufficiently informed. The Journal and Newsletter, having wide dis¬
tribution are not appropriate vehicles for distributing information on progress of ne¬
gotiations or other sensitive matters that are best kept ‘en famiBe 99; hence, this memo
method. Please keep the contents confidential.
MADISON SEMINAR FOLLOW- IIP
Jack McBride, Chairman of the Permanent Convention Committee, immediately
fired off a new faemo to his group incorporating suggestions from the Seminar calling
for widespread participation of members - particularly newer ones - in convention
proceedings. Twelve NAEB people are to be selected to present papers and at each
of the four sessions there will be a chairman, recorder, and three reactors. By so do¬
ing 32 people will be involved on the four sessions devoted to paper presentations.
Jack’s committee is recommending appropriate topics and speakers competent to discuss
them.
At Schwartzwalder's suggestion ,, I have agreed to appoint an ad hoc committee
to study the need and feasibility of an NAEB television network along the lines dis¬
cussed in Madison. Jim Miles (who has video-tape equipment in his back yard) has
agreed to serve as Chariman; other members will be announced shortly. Incidentally,
the Center, USOE and McBride are discussing, next week, plans for the Center’s
role as national distribution center for video instructional material,
PERSONNEL RECRUITMENT
Urgent requests in the past few days for NAEB to suggest personnel for Feder¬
al jobs, again points up the importance of our proposal for a national index , Armand
Hunter, a member of the Title VII Advisory Committee and currently acting as a special
consultant here In Washington to the USOE, has promised me to do all he can to get
action on our proposa 1 this month Part of his willingness crises from the need of US¬
OE to find an immediate replacement for John Meaney, who left June 30 and for whom
Armand is substituting. This job is the Radio-TV specialist in the Ed, Media Branch.
Xt3s a civil service job with a starting salary of $12,210. This job will become increas¬
ing important - especially if the ETV legislation goes thru - and it’s to our interest to
get a good man in this spot.
